description: From Middle English pinden, penden, punden (also as poynen), from Old English *pyndan, ġepyndan (“to impound, shut up, inclose”), from Proto-West Germanic *pundijan (“to impound”). Doublet of poind. Related also to pond.

verbs.description: pind (third-person singular simple present pinds, present participle pinding, simple past and past participle pinded)

entries.meaning: (transitive, now rare or chiefly dialectal) To impound (as cattle), to shut up in a pound.
(transitive, Northern England) To confine within narrow limits, constrain.
